title: Aaron Daggett
text:
Aaron Simon Daggett (June 14, 1837 – May 14, 1938) was a career <a href="United%20States%20Army">United States Army</a> officer. He was the last surviving <a href="Brevet%20%28military%29">brevet</a> <a href="Union%20Army">Union</a> general of the <a href="American%20Civil%20War">American Civil War</a>, and the last surviving general of any grade from the war, when he died one month shy of his 101st birthday in 1938. Daggett was nominated for appointment to the grade of brevet <a href="Brigadier%20general%20%28United%20States%29">brigadier general</a>, to rank from March 13, 1865, by <a href="President%20of%20the%20United%20States">President</a> <a href="Andrew%20Johnson">Andrew Johnson</a> on February 21, 1866 and was confirmed by the <a href="United%20States%20Senate">United States Senate</a> on April 10, 1866. During the war, Daggett fought at <a href="Battle%20of%20Eltham%27s%20Landing">West Point</a>, <a href="Battle%20of%20Gaines%27%20Mill">Gaines' Mill</a>, <a href="Battle%20of%20Garnett%27s%20%26amp%3B%20Golding%27s%20Farm">Golding's Farm</a>, <a href="Battle%20of%20White%20Oak%20Swamp">White Oak Swamp</a>, <a href="Second%20Battle%20of%20Bull%20Run">Second Bull Run</a>, <a href="Battle%20of%20South%20Mountain">South Mountain</a>, <a href="Battle%20of%20Antietam">Antietam</a>, <a href="First%20Battle%20of%20Rappahannock%20Station">Rappahannock Station</a>, <a href="Battle%20of%20Fredericksburg">Fredericksburg</a>, <a href="Battle%20of%20Gettysburg">Battle of Gettysburg</a>, <a href="Battle%20of%20Mine%20Run">Battle of Mine Run</a>, <a href="Battle%20of%20the%20Wilderness">Battle of the Wilderness</a> and <a href="Battle%20of%20Cold%20Harbor">Battle of Cold Harbor</a>. Daggett was a brigadier general of volunteers in the <a href="Spanish%E2%80%93American%20War">Spanish–American War</a>. He was appointed to the brigadier general grade to rank from September 1, 1898 and was mustered out of the volunteers on November 30, 1898. He was promoted to brigadier general in the <a href="Regular%20Army%20%28United%20States%29">Regular Army (United States)</a> ten days before his retirement from the army on March 2, 1901.
Early life and education.
Daggett was born in <a href="Greene%2C%20Maine">Greene, Maine</a>, on June 14, 1837. He was the son of <a href="Yankee">Yankee</a> parents, whose <a href="Puritan">Puritan</a> ancestors came to New England as part of the <a href="Puritan%20migration">Puritan migration</a> from England in 1630. Both of Daggett's grandfathers served in the <a href="American%20Revolutionary%20War">Revolutionary War</a>.
Daggett attended <a href="Bates%20College">Bates College</a> (then called the Maine State Seminary) in <a href="Lewiston%2C%20Maine">Lewiston, Maine</a>, in 1860. He also attended the <a href="Monmouth%20Academy%20%28Maine%29">Monmouth Academy</a> and <a href="Maine%20Wesleyan%20Academy">Maine Wesleyan Academy</a>.
Military career.
Civil War.
Daggett enlisted as a <a href="private%20%28rank%29">private</a> in the <a href="5th%20Maine%20Volunteer%20Infantry%20Regiment">5th Maine Volunteer Infantry Regiment</a> in April 1861, and became a <a href="second%20lieutenant%23United%20States">second lieutenant</a> in May 1861. He was appointed <a href="First%20lieutenant%20%28United%20States%29">first lieutenant</a>, June 24, 1861. He fought at the <a href="First%20Battle%20of%20Bull%20Run">First Battle of Bull Run</a>. He was appointed a <a href="Captain%20%28United%20States%29">captain</a>, August 15, 1861.
Daggett became a <a href="Major%20%28United%20States%29">major</a> of the 5th Maine Infantry Regiment to rank from April 14, 1863. He fought at <a href="Battle%20of%20Salem%20Church">Second Fredericksburg</a>, <a href="Battle%20of%20Gettysburg">Gettysburg</a>, <a href="Mine%20Run%20Campaign">Mine Run</a>, <a href="Battle%20of%20the%20Wilderness">the Wilderness</a>, and <a href="Battle%20of%20Cold%20Harbor">Cold Harbor</a> where he was wounded on May 30, 1864.
Daggett was mustered out of the volunteers on July 24, 1864. On January 23, 1865, he was appointed <a href="Lieutenant%20colonel%20%28United%20States%29">lieutenant colonel</a> of the 5th United States Veteran Volunteer Infantry Regiment. He was appointed brevet <a href="Colonel%20%28United%20States%29">colonel</a>, March 3, 1865. He had brevet appointments as a major in the <a href="Regular%20Army%20%28United%20States%29">Regular Army</a> for gallant and meritorious services at Rappahannock Station and as <a href="Lieutenant%20colonel%20%28United%20States%29">lieutenant colonel</a> for services at the Wilderness, both to rank from March 3, 1865. He was again mustered out of the volunteers, May 10, 1865.
On February 21, 1866, <a href="President%20of%20the%20United%20States">President</a> <a href="Andrew%20Johnson">Andrew Johnson</a> nominated Daggett for appointment to the grade of brevet <a href="Brigadier%20general%20%28United%20States%29">brigadier general</a> of volunteers, to rank from March 13, 1865, and the <a href="United%20States%20Senate">United States Senate</a> confirmed the appointment on April 10, 1866.
Daggett believed in the <a href="abolitionism%20in%20the%20United%20States">abolition</a> of slavery and fought alongside African-American soldiers during the Civil War while serving with the 5th Maine Infantry Regiment. He was also a strong supporter of the <a href="temperance%20movement">temperance movement</a> and gave public lectures on the topic. Daggett was a member of the <a href="Presbyterian">Presbyterian</a> church.
Subsequent military career.
On July 28, 1866, Daggett became a captain in the <a href="16th%20Infantry%20Regiment%20%28United%20States%29">16th U.S. Infantry Regiment</a>. He was transferred to the <a href="2nd%20Infantry%20Regiment%20%28United%20States%29">2nd U.S. Infantry Regiment</a> on April 17, 1869. He was appointed major in the <a href="13th%20Infantry%20Regiment%20%28United%20States%29">13th U.S. Infantry Regiment</a> on February 2, 1892. He was appointed lieutenant colonel in the <a href="25th%20Infantry%20Regiment%20%28United%20States%29">25th U.S. Infantry Regiment</a> on October 1, 1895.
In his military career after the Civil War, Aaron Daggett went on to fight in the <a href="Indian%20Wars">Indian Wars</a>, in which he received a purple heart, the <a href="Spanish%E2%80%93American%20War">Spanish–American War</a> in China, and the Philippines and received another <a href="Purple%20Heart">Purple Heart</a> and the <a href="5/16%20inch%20star">Gold Star</a>. (These quoted ref. do not state awarding of the a-fore referenced Medals. Data needs to be sourced from National Military Archives.)
During the Spanish–American War, Daggett was temporarily appointed to the brigadier general grade to rank from September 1, 1898 and was mustered out of the volunteers on November 30, 1898. He was present at the <a href="Battle%20of%20San%20Juan%20Hill">Battle of San Juan Hill</a>.
On February 21, 1900 Daggett became a brigadier general of the regular U.S. Army before retiring on March 2, 1901 to <a href="Auburn%2C%20Maine">Auburn, Maine</a>.
Death and legacy.
Aaron S. Daggett died <a href="centenarian">at the age of 100</a> at his home in <a href="West%20Roxbury">West Roxbury</a>, <a href="Massachusetts">Massachusetts</a> on May 14, 1938, making him the last surviving brevet or full, substantive rank Union general of the Civil War. He was buried at Old Valley Cemetery, Greene Corner, Maine.
Daggett Terrace (Veterans Village Subdivision) in New Port Richey Florida is named after Aaron Daggett.
